author: Deleted User
content: In Proposer/Builder Sparation designs, will a builder's bid increase the proposer's balance on the consensus layer? In other words, a builder uses EL eth and instantly sends it to the CL when he wins a bid? Or will EL eth stay on the EL and go to the proposer via an EL address of his choice?

author: Deleted User
content: I kinda like the idea of builders' ETH getting locked up on the CL and requiring proposers to initiate a withdraw to make that ETH liquid again

author: metachris_
content: it would be great to see if mergemock also has this issue (although mergemock does things slightly differently than the real thing)

author: ralexstokes
content: <@456226577798135808> yeah there are a few options here, if we do the builder to proposer accounting with locked ETH then it also naturally means we have a place to implement builder slashing which imo will be useful

author: ralexstokes
content: its also simpler to just do accounting in one place, barring any deeper integration of the EL and CL layers post-merge

author: ralexstokes
content: doing something cross-layer is possible, just more complex and it is always good to minimize consensus complexity

author: Deleted User
content: what I had in mind was more like the builder's bid is ETH that lives on the execution layer and it gets burned when his bid wins, and the proposer's CL balance simply increases by the corresponding amount on the same slot where the block is proposed. I guess the accounting gets tricky, but with push withdrawals the CL can will be able to affect the EL's state more directly from my understanding

author: ralexstokes
content: i do like builders being bonded and that is all the most straightforward if we just have "slots" for builders at the CL

author: ralexstokes
content: we could add a 'builder debit' message like the 'withdrawal' message that applies EL mutations from the CL, but again it makes the whole thing more complicated

author: ralexstokes
content: i think that a "builder" role under PBS is "big enough" that it is not a problem to expect them to be bonded on the CL
